SSZ-13 zeolite was synthesized from fly ash using a combined alkali fusion hydrothermal method. The optimal synthesis parameters are as follows: NaOH/FA=1.4, SiO2/Al2O3=50, H2O/SiO2=1800, TMAda-OH/Al2O3=7, the amount of SSZ-13-seed=10%, and crystallization time and temperature were 160 °C and 40 h. Based on this, a series of fly ash-based Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts were prepared using three different methods and tested in catalytic oxidation with H2O2 for NO removal. The experiment results showed that the NO removal efficiency catalyzed by Fe-SSZ-13-SSIE, Fe-SSZ-13-LIE and Fe-SSZ-13-IM were 78%, 87% and 84%, respectively. ESR was used to detect hydroxyl radicals, UV-vis, XPS and H2-TPR were applied to test the composition, state and distribution of iron species, while NH3-TPD and Py-FTIR were performed to analyze the intensity and type of acidic sites, and finally to determine the relationship between catalyst structure, active species and catalytic performance in combination with NO removal experiments. The catalytic oxidation mechanism analysis revealed that the excellent catalytic performance can be attributed to the dual function of strong Brønsted acidity on the surface and isolated Fe3+ with high dispersion, which can rapidly decompose H2O2 into ·OH and efficiently achieve NO oxidation. In conclusion, the preparation of fly ash catalysts has great potential for achieving the dual function of waste utilization and pollutant removal. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fe-SSZ-13 Isolated Fe3+ species Brønsted acid sites Hydroxyl radicals Catalytic oxidation Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Coal fly ash (CFA) is a solid residual waste from coal combustion in power plants that has caused significant environmental damage, resource waste, and health risks [1]. Fly ash emissions have increased due to the rapid expansion of the economy. However, most fly ash is used in the building materials and road construction industries, and there are limited opportunities for producing high-value commodities from fly ash. The majority of fly ash is composed of silica, alumina, iron oxide, calcium oxide, and unburned carbon. The highest concentrations of SiO2 and Al2O3 are a significant component of this abundant resource. The successful extraction of useful materials from fly ash will help to create a circular economy and save costs while also reducing environmental impact. The production of various zeolites from fly ash is an effective approach to using fly ash. At present, fly ash-based zeolites such as A [2], X [3], Y [4], P [5], ZSM-5 [6], β [7], MCM-41 [8], SBA-15 [9], SSZ-13 [10], and SAPO-34 [11] have been successfully synthesized. The typical structural features of SSZ-13 are CHA cage structured zeolites with 3-dimensional structures, including octet rings and cross channels. It has the advantages of a simple structure, ordered pore structure, good hydrothermal stability, and a large number of surface plasmonic acid centers. However, the challenges in SSZ-13 synthesis are the long crystallization time and the high cost of organic structure-directing agents. Many scholars have synthesized SSZ-13 zeolite using some relatively inexpensive organic structure-directing agents (e.g., TEAOH [12]), but the cost saving is limited, and subsequent calcination is also required to remove the template agent to efficiently nucleate and crystallize SSZ-13. Some researchers have also attempted to synthesize SSZ-13 using different zeolites (β [13], Y [14], ZSM-35 [15], etc.), but the synthesis cost of these parent zeolites is extremely high. However, it is important to use the abundant silica and aluminum sources in fly ash to synthesize SSZ-13 zeolites, both to lower the synthesis costs, to achieve solid waste utilization, and to apply them in catalytic H2O2 oxidation of NO to achieve efficient denitrification. The combination of transition metal elements and zeolites can improve both their catalytic efficiency, as Fe is more easily dispersed onto the zeolite skeleton, and the crystallization process of Fe and zeolite leads to the formation of excellent acidity and redox properties. The preparation process is directly associated with the type, distribution, and form of Fe species present in zeolites, which in turn affects the catalytic properties of Fe-based catalysts. The most commonly used methods for introducing Fe into zeolites include impregnation, ion exchange (liquid/solid states), and hydrothermal synthesis, and good dispersion of Fe species in zeolite pore channels can be achieved by optimizing the preparation process parameters. Furthermore, multiple types of Fe species, such as isolated Fe3+ species, small FexOy clusters, and large Fe2O3 particles are often found in Fe/zeolite catalysts. The preparation method influences the catalytic activity of different types of Fe species in a specific process [16]. Shi et al. [17] used enhanced aqueous ion exchange (IA) and solid state ion exchange (SS) techniques to obtain two Fe-based catalysts (Fe-ZSM-5(IA), Fe-ZSM-5(SS)). The different preparation methods impart different forms of iron ions in catalysts. Fe-ZSM-5(IA) has the largest number of Fe3+ ions, a few α-Fe2O3, Fe3O4 species, and octahedrally symmetrical Fe3+ complexes, whereas Fe-ZSM-5(SS) has α-Fe2O3 and Fe3O4 as the most predominant iron species. Due to the abundance of Fe3+ ions which play an important role as active sites in SCR reactions, Fe-ZSM-5(IA) catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic effects. Romero-Sáez et al. [18] obtained three Fe-ZSM-5 catalysts using liquid ion exchange, impregnation, and solid-state ion exchange methods, and provided a detailed description of the active sites responsible for oxidation. The addition of Fe resulted in increased activity and stability, also, Fe2O3 nanoparticles present in the additional backbone of ZSM-5 zeolite were discovered to be the main active iron species rather than acidic sites. The combined activity of impregnation or solid-state ion exchange catalysts was not as good as that of ion exchange catalysts. Chen et al. [16] used impregnation, ion exchange, and hydrothermal methods to prepare three Fe/Beta catalysts. The experimental results revealed that different preparation methods might yield varied Fe species and amounts of acid sites, with the hydrothermal method yielding the highest content of isolated Fe3+ species with highest acid concentration, resulting in the best catalytic performance. The energy crisis has brought the concept of "green chemistry" to the forefront, and the catalytic oxidation of NO by H2O2 using catalysts is a promising green catalytic process. In addition, the synthesis of catalysts from fly ash for denitrification experiments can achieve the purpose of solid waste utilization and accelerate the process of catalytic oxidation, which has important research significance. In this study, the fly ash-based SSZ-13 zeolite was not only successfully prepared using an alkali fusion-assisted hydrothermal method, but also the optimal preparation parameters and the effect of each parameter on the formation of SSZ-13 zeolite was determined. The Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts were also prepared using three preparation methods, and the effects of the different preparation methods on the state and nature of the Fe species present in the zeolites, as well as the nature of the acidic sites in the catalysts were investigated. The properties of these active species were also correlated with the catalytic properties during NO oxidation to determine the catalytic oxidation mechanism. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Chemicals The fly ash used for the synthesis of zeolite was obtained from the Pingshuo thermal power plant in Shanxi Province, and it had the following chemical composition: 51.361% SiO2, 30.371% Al2O3, 4.817% Fe2O3, 1.156% TiO2 and 6.42% CaO, with SiO2 and Al2O3 accounting for more than 80%. Sodium hydroxide (NaOH), N, N, N-Trimethyladamantan (TMAda-OH), ferric nitrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O), Aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), Sodium silicate (Na2O·3.3SiO2, 34%) and colloidal silica (40%) were purchased from the Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. Commercial SSZ-13 was purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All the chemicals used were of analytical grade and did not require any further special processing. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts The elemental composition, fly ash content, and synthetic catalysts were determined using an ARL 9900 X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, America). The physical phase components of catalysts were analyzed using Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) performed on an ULTIMA IV X-ray diffractometer (Japan). The microscopic morphology and structure of the sample surface were examined using JSM-IT200 Scanning electronic microscopy (SEM) (Japan). The specific surface areas, pore volume, and textural properties were determined by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm of the gas adsorption method using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 gas adsorption analyzer. A Bia-Rad FTS 165 Fourier infrared spectroscopy analyzer (FTIR) was used to determine the oxygen-containing functional groups in catalysts. Temperature-programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption with NH3 (NH3-TPD) was analyzed on a chemisorption analyzer (AutoChem II 2920) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). To determine the nature and the distribution of Fe, ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV-Vis) was performed on a Shimizu UV-3600 spectrophotometer, capturing wavelengths ranging from 190 to 900 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 instrument to qualitatively determine the ionic state of Fe. Electron spin resonance (ESR) spectral acquisition was performed using BMPO as a spin trap on a Bruker A300-10/12 electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometer, which is used to detect reactive oxygen species during the reaction. The Py-FTIR spectra obtained using the Bruker TENSOR 27 spectrometer allowed for the quantification of Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites. 2.3 Synthesis of FA-SSZ-13 zeolite Raw fly ash was ground and sieved using a 75 μm screen for the synthesis of a fly ash-based SSZ-13 zeolite. A mixture of fly ash and NaOH with a mass ratio of 1:1.4 was ground and the homogeneous mixture was calcined in a muffle furnace at 873 K for 2 h, in the alkali fusion process. The alkali-melted product was then cooled to room temperature and ground into a fine powder, transferred to a 500 ml three-mouth beaker. An appropriate amount of deionized water, sodium silicate (Na2O·3.3SiO2), and organic structure directing agents (TMAda-OH) were added sequentially at a constant temperature of 80 °C with continuous stirring in an oil bath for 2 h to obtain the gel solution. Na2O·3.3SiO2 was selected as the silica source in the preparation process because it is cheaper than colloidal silica. The molar ratios of each component were set at 50SiO2: 1Al2O3: 7TMAda-OH: 1800H2O. The suspended solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and crystallized in an oven at 160 °C for 48 h. After the autoclave had naturally cooled, it was washed and filtered to approximately neutral pH, then dried for 6 h at 100 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 5 h to remove TMAda-OH and obtain Na-SSZ-13. Finally, the ion exchange process was carried out, which included ion exchange with 1 mol/L NH4Cl solution at 80 °C for 8 h to convert to NH4-SSZ-13, washing multiple times with deionized water to remove chloride ions, drying at 100 °C for 6 h, and calcining at 550 °C for 5 h to obtain H-SSZ-13. Fig. S2 depicts the schematic of the alkali fusion hydrothermal method for preparing H-SSZ-13 from fly ash. 2.4 Synthesis of SSZ-13-seed It is well known that the use of OSDAs has obvious disadvantages:(i) they are expensive; (ii) they require high-temperature calcination for removal and produce harmful gasses such as nitrogen oxides (NOX) and carbon dioxide (CO2); (iii) the use of OSDAs generates large amounts of effluent and pollutes the environment; and (iv) the energy released by high-temperature calcination can combine with the water formed and is extremely harmful to the inorganic structure of zeolites. Several drawbacks impede the practical application OSDAs. The best solution to these problems is to limit the use of OSDAs or to achieve OSDAs-free synthesis of zeolites, which can be accomplished by introducing zeolite seeds. In this study, the crystallization of SSZ-13 was efficiently promoted by introducing SSZ-13 seeds with a small amount of TMAda-OH in synergy with each other. The SSZ-13 seeds were synthesized according to published literature with slight modifications [19]. NaOH was added to deionized water and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Subsequently, the aluminum source (Al(NO3)3·9H2O), silicon source (colloidal silica), and OSDAs (TMAda-OH) was added slowly and continuously stirred for 3 h at 80 °C. The molar ratio of each part was 34SiO2: 1Al2O3: 6Na2O: 3.6TMAda-OH: 1400H2O. The resultant gel mixture was placed in a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and crystallized at 160 °C in a static oven for 4 days. The solid product was recovered by filtration, washed with deionized water to pH neutrality, dried for 6 h at 100 °C and calcined in air at 550 °C for 5 h. The sample was labeled as SSZ-13-seed. Fig. S3 displays the XRD patterns of self-made SSZ-13-seed and commercial SSZ-13 zeolite, in which it is evident that their characteristic peaks are highly consistent. 2.5 Preparation of Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts 2.5.1 Preparation by impregnation method (IM) The appropriate amount of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O solution was configured and slowly added dropwise to 3.0 g of H-FA-SSZ-13 after the saturated water uptake of 3.0 g of SSZ-13 samples (H-FA-SSZ-13) was calculated. The mixture was left to stand at room temperature for 24 h. Finally, the mixture was dried at 100 °C for 6 h and then placed in a muffle furnace for calcination at 550 °C for 5 h. The obtained sample was labeled as Fe-SSZ-13-IM. 2.5.2 Preparation by liquid ion exchange method (LIE) Na-FA-SSZ-13 (3.0 g) samples were stirred in 300 mL of 1 M NH4Cl solution at 80 °C for 8 h. The NH4-SSZ-13 sample was then stirred in 100 mL of 0.1 M Fe(NO3)3·9H2O solution at 80 °C for 2 h. After that, the mixture was washed, dried and calcined at 550 °C for 5 h. The ion exchange process was performed three times to obtain the final catalyst. The obtained sample was labeled as Fe-SSZ-13-LIE. 2.5.3 Solid state ion exchange method (SSIE) After dissolving 0.36 g of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O in 10 g of distilled water, 3.0 g of NH4-FA-SSZ-13 powder was added while stirring. The mixture was then evaporated under vacuum using a rotary evaporator and dried at 110 °C for 6 h to avoid liquid ion exchange. After drying, the mixture was thoroughly ground using a ball mill for 20 min before being calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 °C for 5 h to obtain Fe-SSZ-13-SSIE, a solid ion exchange sample. 2.6 NO removal performance test The experimental setup for catalytic oxidation is shown in Fig. S4 and consists of four major components: simulated flue gas control, catalytic oxidation reaction, absorption, and exhaust gas detection. The specific NO removal experiments are described in the supplementary data. The corresponding removal efficiency was determined under a steady state based on the concentration of NO in the flue gas analyzer before and after the reaction, and three tests are required each time to ensure more reasonable and accurate experimental results. Eq. (1) shows the calculation formula. (1) η = ( C in − C out C in ) × 100 % Where, η is NO removal efficiency (%), C in is the inlet concentration of NO and C out is the outlet concentration of NO in the simulated flue gas (mg/m3). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation of fly ash-based SSZ-13 zeolite 3.1.1 XRF Table 1 shows the chemical composition of raw fly ash and the products of alkali fusion with different NaOH/FA ratios, which is important for quantifying SiO2 and Al2O3. The specific content of SiO2 and Al2O3 provides the main source of Si and Al for the synthesis of zeolites. Furthermore, when compared to raw fly ash, the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio increases sharply with increasing NaOH/FA ratios. The SiO2/Al2O3 ratio significantly influences the physico-chemical properties of zeolites and changes the entire zeolite conversion process. However, other trace components (Fe and Ca) are considered as exchangeable cations that not only affect the composition and crystal structure of zeolites but also interfere with their textural properties (pore size and surface area). 3.1.2 XRD The formation of a highly crystalline SSZ-13 zeolite (JCPDS 47-0762) is indicated by the distinctive characteristic peaks at 2θ =9.58°,12.97°,14.01°, 16.16°, 18.00°, 20.82°, 25.21°, 30.94° and 31.41° [1,10]. This is due to the structural rearrangement of FA during alkali fusion and hydrothermal treatment, i.e., the conversion of the main phases quartz and mullite into silicate and aluminate, and the XRD patterns of fly ash before and after alkali fusion are shown in Fig. S1. Consequently, the raw FA was successfully transformed into SSZ-13 zeolite. Too high or too low alkali content is detrimental to zeolite synthesis, as shown in Fig. 1 (a). As the NaOH/FA ratio increased from 1.0 to 1.4, the characteristic peak representing SSZ-13 increased gradually. However, the NaOH/FA ratio increased to 1.6, the synthesis of SSZ-13 failed, probably as a result of the direct transformation of FA into the most stable crystal structure, or even agglomeration. Therefore, NaOH/FA=1.4 is chosen as the optimal alkali to ash ratio. As demonstrated in Fig. 1(b), the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio (30, 50, 80, 100) of the initial sodium aluminosilicate gel composition, had a significant effect on the crystallization process. When the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio increased from 30 to 80, all SSZ-13 characteristic peaks could be observed, and their intensities initially increased and then slightly decreased. As the SiO2/Al2O3 ratio increased to 100, some of the diffraction peaks typical of SSZ-13 were visible on the pattern, along with other impure peaks. Therefore, the optimum ratio of SiO2/Al2O3 was set at 50. H2O is the medium for zeolite synthesis, in which nutrients, including silica and alumina, are dissolved for crystal nucleation and growth. As the results, the effect of the H2O/Al2O3 ratio on the formation of SSZ-13 zeolite was investigated during the preparation process in the range from 900 to 2500, as shown in Fig. 1(c). The characteristic peaks increased as the H2O/Al2O3 ratio varied from 900 to 1800, while only slight changes were shown as the H2O/Al2O3 ratio varied from 1800 to 2500. Therefore, the H2O/Al2O3 ratio was kept at 1800 for the synthesis of SSZ-13. Fig. 1(d) shows the XRD patterns of samples prepared with different concentrations of TMAda-OH. For comparison, the synthesized sample without the addition of OSDAs was also examined, and it was discovered that the characteristic diffraction peaks of the obtained products did not agree with the characteristic peaks of SSZ-13. It can be noticed that the intensity of the characteristic peaks of SSZ-13 molecular sieve increases with the increase of the addition of the template agent. When the molar ratio of TMAda-OH/Al2O3 was increased to 7, a fairly good crystallization effect was already harvested, and the intensity of the characteristic peaks of the samples started to weaken instead when the molar ratio continued to be increased. Therefore, the optimum molar ratio of TMAda-OH/SiO2 is 7. As shown in Fig. 1(e), the amount of seeds under optimal hydrothermal treatment conditions has a significant effect on the crystallization process. It is noteworthy that when there are no crystal seeds in the aluminosilicate gel and the TMAda-OH/Al2O3 ratio is 7, the crystallization products of SSZ-13 have started to appear, but there are also some characteristic peaks that do not belong to SSZ-13. At a seed addition of 2.5%, the typical diffraction peaks belonging to SSZ-13 have become clearly visible, and as the seed amount is increased from 5% to 7.5%, the structures of the prepared samples all show strong diffraction peaks of SSZ-13 with increasing intensity, indicating the successful crystallization of SSZ-13. When the seed amount was further increased, the crystalline intensity did not change much. For economic reasons, the seed amount for further synthesis of SSZ-13 by this seed-assisted process could be set at 7.5%. The introduction of seeds significantly reduces the use of TMAda-OH. The hydrothermal treatment time also affected the synthesis results (Fig. 1(f)). When the hydrothermal temperature was set at 160 °C, the hydrothermal time of the samples ranged from 24 h to 60 h. All samples exhibited typical SSZ-13 characteristic peaks. The XRD peaks with a crystallization time of 24 h had a clear arch, which was likely due to the poor crystallinity. When the crystallization time reached 36 h, the arching disappeared and the pattern became intense and sharp. The intensity of the diffraction peaks increased from 36 to 48 h, and further extension of the hydrothermal time decreased the diffraction peaks to some extent. These findings suggested that SSZ-13 zeolites can be successfully synthesized by crystallization at 160 °C for 48 h. The purpose of introducing SSZ-13-seed is to shorten the synthesis cycle, improve the quality of molecular sieves and reduce the use of expensive template agents (TMAda-OH). Fig. 1(g) shows the effect of the variation of the TMAda-OH/Al2O3 ratio on the synthesis effect when the addition of SSZ-13 seeds is 10% and the synthesis time is reduced to 40 h. It can be found that the presence of SSZ-13 seeds not only reduces the synthesis time, but also greatly reduces the need for a template agent, and the characteristic SSZ-13 zeolite product can be successfully synthesized when the TMAda-OH/Al2O3 ratio is 3, further attaining the goal of cost reduction. 3.1.3 FTIR FTIR spectra were obtained in the 400–4000 cm−1 scan range, providing detailed information on the functional groups present in the prepared samples. Fig. 2 depicts the FTIR results of SSZ-13 samples corresponding to all parameter variations. The band at around 540 cm−1 was interpreted as a double six-membered ring structure forming a CHA framework, while the bands at 640 cm−1 and 680 cm−1 were attributed to stretching and bending T-O vibrations in silicon-oxygen or aluminum-oxide tetrahedrons. The band at 805 cm−1 could be explained as symmetric stretching vibrations of Al-O in SSZ-13, the band at 1077 cm−1 as asymmetric stretching vibrations of O-Si-O or O-Al-O, and the bands at 1635 cm−1 and 3444 cm−1 bands to the stretching and bending vibrations of NH in the ammonium ion of TMAda-OH [20,21]. Therefore, FT-IR analysis confirms that the typical vibrational frequency of SSZ-13 zeolite can be synthesized from fly ash. 3.1.4 Morphological observations SEM was used to determine the microscopic morphology of all samples. Fig. 3 (a) shows the typical smooth spherical shape of the original FA. The presence of spherical particles indicates a higher proportion of Si and Al, both of which are precursors for zeolite synthesis. Fig. 3(b) illustrates that the spherical shape of fly ash is sufficiently disrupted after NaOH treatment and that the alkali fusion treatment effectively promotes the conversion of fly ash to silicates and aluminosilicates. The morphology of fly ash significantly changes after alkali fusion, displaying irregular rough and loose granularity. The action of NaOH at higher temperatures causes Si and Al to dissolve, and subsequent hydrothermal processes induce nucleation, crystal growth, and phase transformation, i.e. internal changes in the crystal structure energy [10,22]. Fig. 3(c) shows a commercial SSZ-13 zeolite product with a typical cubic crystal structure. Fig. 3(d) shows pure phase SSZ-13 zeolite crystals obtained after alkali fusion combined with the hydrothermal process, the rhombic polyhedral structure is visible, and a small amount of other shapes is observed, confirming the formation of zeolite. Fig. 3(e) shows the Fe-SSZ-13 product obtained by the liquid ion exchange method retains the typical CHA topology of SSZ-13 and the elemental distribution mapping (Fig. 3(f)) indicates the successful loading of Fe species into the SSZ-13 zeolite. 3.2 Synthesis and catalytic properties of Fe-SSZ-13 3.2.1 XRF The Si/Al ratios and Fe/Al ratios of the Fe/SSZ-13 catalysts obtained from the different preparation methods were determined by XRF testing and are listed in Table 2 . It is clear that the Si/Al ratios and Fe/Al ratios of the catalysts are similar, facilitating the analysis of their catalytic performance for comparison. 3.2.2 XRD XRD was used to characterize the crystalline structures of the parent SSZ-13 and three Fe-SSZ-13 samples prepared by different methods, and the findings are shown in Fig. 4 . Gratifyingly, the intensities of these diffraction peaks in the XRD patterns of Fe-SSZ-13 samples obtained from various preparations did not differ significantly from those of SSZ-13. This indicates that the introduction of Fe did not result in significant changes in SSZ-13 zeolites. When the Fe loading is more than 5 wt.%, it can be detected by powder X-ray diffraction analysis, and the characteristic peaks (2θ=33° and 36°) of α-Fe2O3 were discovered [23,24]. However, the characteristic peaks on both the Fe-SSZ-13-LIE and Fe-SSZ-13-IM catalysts were weaker, whereas the characteristic peaks on the Fe-SSZ-13-SSIE catalyst were stronger, indicating that the SSZ-13 zeolite can be an ideal carrier for dispersed Fe species and also that Fe species in the form of exchange ions or small agglomerates on the Fe-SSZ-13-LIE and Fe-SSZ-13-IM catalysts are better dispersed. 3.2.3 FTIR Fig. 5 shows the FTIR spectra of the parent SSZ-13 and Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts. Only the Fe-SSZ-13 catalyst can be seen in an IR band at 1262 cm−1, which may be associated with the presence of Fe3+ species [25]. The presence of OH groups and hydroxyl groups bridged with Al-OH-Si or Si-OH-Fe is shown by the peaks centered at 3611 and 3737 cm−1, respectively [10]. The introduction of Fe did not result in significant changes to the SSZ-13 structure, which is consistent with the XRD findings. 3.2.4 N2 adsorption-desorption The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm can be used to determine the textural properties of different catalysts. Aluminosilicate microporous zeolite is a material with a high specific surface area. Fig. 6 shows that the N2 adsorption and desorption processes are reversible on all catalysts. According to the IUPAC classification, the isotherms of all catalysts are type І, which is a characteristic of microporous materials. Iron incorporation changes the specific surface area and microporous volume of zeolite, and iron incorporation increases the specific surface area and microporous volume of Fe-SSZ-13 zeolite. However, pore size decreases, owing primarily to partial blockage of zeolite pore channels. As shown in Table 2, the Fe-SSZ-13-IM catalyst has the smallest specific surface area and pore volume in Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts because diffusion is the main force for iron loading on SSZ-13 zeolite during the impregnation process, and capillary action attracts large amounts of Fe ions into the zeolite pore channels, making the pore channels prone to partial blocking by Fe species. In contrast, Fe-SSZ-13-LIE has a large specific surface area and pore volume, indicating that the blocking of iron species has no significant effect on its pore structure. Furthermore, the textural properties have a positive effect on the activity of the catalyst. A larger surface area and pore volume can enable better dispersion of active species, which can help to increase the number of active sites in the catalytic reaction process. 3.2.5 H2-TPR H2-TPR measurements were used to determine the reduction of Fe species in different catalysts. The different reduction peaks imply that multiple Fe species coexist in the Fe-SSZ-13 zeolite as shown in Fig. 7 . Isolated Fe3+ is first reduced to Fe2+ at low temperatures before being reduced further to Fe0 at high temperatures. That is, the peaks at 350–640 °C correspond to the partial reduction of Fe3+(Fe2O3) to Fe2+ (Fe3O4/FeO) at different ion exchange sites (extra-framework/framework), assigned to isolated Fe3+ and binuclear/oligomeric Fe-oxygen cations, respectively [24,26]. The peak at about 650 °C can be explained by the reduction of Fe3O4/FeO to Fe0, while the peak above 800 °C may be associated with the reduction of stable Fe2+ to Fe0. Thus, the intensity of the peaks at 426 and 537 °C for the Fe-SSZ-13-LIE catalyst is more pronounced for both peaks, which might be attributed to Fe3+ reduction to Fe2+ under different interactions of Fe2O3 with SSZ-13 zeolite or at different positions in the catalyst structure [27]. The third peak appearing around 760 °C corresponds to Fe2+ reduction to Fe0. Higher temperatures are required to achieve this reduction because Fe2+ corresponds to ions in extra-frame positions, and the reduction of Fe2+ to Fe0 in the framework can easily result in the collapse of the zeolite structure [18]. The Fe-SSZ-13-IM catalyst exhibits a similar display of three reduction signals of similar intensity, with the first two signals appearing at 434 and 518 °C, corresponding to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe2+, and the third signal appearing at around 656 °C corresponding to the reduction of magnetite (Fe3O4) to FeO. The Fe-SSZ-13-SSIE catalyst also exhibited three signals centered at 453, 621, and 766 °C corresponding to the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+, Fe3O4 to FeO, and Fe2+ to Fe0, respectively. In Fig. 7, the intensity and area of the depletion peaks of Fe-SSZ-13-LIE catalysts are significantly greater, implying a higher amount of monomeric and oligomeric FexOy clusters [28]. 3.2.6 XPS XPS was performed to determine the type and valence state of surface elements in the catalyst Fig. 8 ). From the Fe 2p spectra (Fig. 8(a)), two distinct sets of doublet peaks corresponding to Fe 2p3/2 (708.0–715.0 eV) and Fe 2p1/2 (721.0–730.0 eV) were observed, revealing the presence of Fe3+ originating from Fe2O3 [29,30]. The Fe3+ and Fe2+ on the catalyst surface were obtained by fitting according to different binding energies of Fe elements in Fe 2p3/2. Fitted peaks of Fe 2p3/2 around 710.7 eV and 712.8 eV in Fe-SSZ-13 are respectively attributed to Fe2+ and Fe3+ [31]. The Fe-SSZ-13-LIE catalyst has the highest levels of Fe3+, and the reduction of Fe3+ to Fe2+ is the rate-determining step for decomposition of H2O2 to produce hydroxyl radicals [32], which occupy an important position in oxidation. The lower binding energy of Fe3+ in Fe-SSZ-13-LIE compared to Fe-SSZ-13-IM and Fe-SSZ-13-SSIE indicates that Fe atoms have a lower density of electron clouds, which facilitates electron transfer from H2O2 to Fe3+, thereby promoting the generation of hydroxyl radicals [33]. According to integrated peak areas of Fe-based catalysts (Table 3 ), the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratios are all greater than 1, indicating that Fe3+ is the dominant Fe species on catalysts with Fe2O3 and the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratios for the three Fe-based catalysts are in the order: Fe-SSZ-13-LIE> Fe-SSZ-13-SSIE> Fe-SSZ-13-IM. The higher Fe3+ species levels are reduced to Fe2+, combined with H2O2 to produce hydroxyl radicals through Fenton oxidation reactions, which can be often described via Eqs. (2)–(4) [32,34]. But if the Fe2+ concentration is too high it is not conducive to the oxidation of NO, because too much Fe2+ will not react with H2O2 to produce ·OH, but is more likely to react with ·OH to produce FeOH2+ (Eq. (5))[35]. In Fig. 8(b), two peaks are observed around 530.2 and 532.7 eV, revealing the presence of different oxygen species. The peak around 530.2 eV is allocated to Fe species-associated oxygen, while the peak at 532.7 eV is defined for the Si-O band [16]. For the Fe-SSZ-13-LIE catalyst, the peak around 530.2 eV is the most pronounced, implying the enrichment of the indicated Fe species on the zeolite surface. (2) F e 3 + + H 2 O 2 → F e 2 + + HO 2 · + H + (3) F e 3 + + HO 2 · → F e 2 + + O 2 + H + (4) F e 2 + + H 2 O 2 → F e 3 + + · OH + O H − (5) F e 2 + + · OH → FeO H 2 + 3.2.7 UV-Vis spectroscopy Fig. 9 shows the UV-Vis spectra of Fe-SSZ-13 with different preparation methods. The UV-Vis spectroscopy can be used to assess the nature and distributions of different Fe species. The ligand to metal Bands (O→Fe3+) charge transfer transitions between 200 and 300 nm are defined as isolated Fe3+ ions occupying ion-exchange positions, transitions between 300 and 400 nm are attributed to oligomeric Fe species as FexOy clusters and transitions higher than 400 nm belong to crystalline Fe2O3 particles located outside zeolite pores [36–38]. Sizes of Fe2O3 particles can be reacted according to slopes of spectral bands above 500 nm [39]. The slopes of bands above 500 nm for Fe-based catalysts are arranged as: Fe-SSZ-13-IM>Fe-SSZ-13-LIE>Fe-SSZ-13-SSIE. Therefore, Fe2O3 particles in Fe-based catalysts obtained by impregnation have largest particle sizes. Relative proportions of Fe species in catalysts obtained by different preparation methods were quantified based on deconvolution spectra (Table 4 ). Findings from specific split-peak fit are presented in Fig. S5. The nature and distributions of Fe species are shown. Monomeric Fe3+ materials were predominant in the Fe-SSZ-13-LIE catalyst, while the Fe-SSZ-13-IM catalyst showed a higher percentage of agglomerated Fe2O3, in accordance with H2-TPR findings in Fig. 7. The high percentage of isolated Fe3+ and the low percentage of Fe2O3 particles indicate a high degree of dispersion of Fe species in SSZ-13 zeolites [37]. Findings from UV-Vis spectroscopy, have shown that although isolated Fe3+ ions, Fe(Ⅲ)xOy clusters and Fe2O3 particles co-exist in Fe-SSZ-13 [40].The Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts obtained by three different preparation methods have different redox properties and catalytic activities. Fe-SSZ-13-LIE has the highest catalytic activity, most likely due to the high amount of Fe3+ species it has. 3.2.8 ESR As previously reported [41–43], the introduction of iron enhances the decomposition of H2O2 into hydroxyl radicals, which are important reactive oxygen species involved in oxidation-reaction processes. To determine the reaction mechanisms, DMPO spin-trap ESR was used to monitor the radical species involved in the Fe-SSZ-13+H2O2 system. In Fig. 10 , the ESR spectra in all four measured samples exhibit 4-fold characteristic peaks of typical DMPO-·OH adducts with intensity ratios of 1:2:2:1 and intensity magnitudes in the order: Fe-SSZ-13-LIE>Fe-SSZ-13-IM>Fe-SSZ-13-SSIE. The ·OH yield is proportional to peak intensities of the ESR spectra [44]. That is, more ·OH radicals are produced in the Fe-SSZ-13-LIE+H2O2 system, and the removal efficiency of NO was highest, implying that hydroxyl radicals, which are key reactive oxygen species, achieved NO oxidation. The oxidation of NO with ·OH occurs through the following reactions Eqs. (6)–(9). (6) NO + · OH → HN O 2 (7) NO + · OH → · H + N O 2 (8) N O 2 + · OH → HN O 3 (9) HN O 2 + · OH → HN O 3 + · H 3.2.9 NH3-TPD The acidity of Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts obtained by different preparation methods can be quantified by NH3-TPD measurements (Fig. 11 ), while the amounts of corresponding weak and strong acidic sites are shown in Table 5 . Generally, two NH3 desorption peaks at different temperatures can be seen, indicating the presence of two types of acidic sites. Peaks centered at 140–230 °C are attributed to weakly bound NH3 on weak acid sites, and the peak around 400–550 °C is attributed to NH3 desorption from structural strong acid sites [26,45], which have a close association with catalytic oxidation performance in the NO removal process [44]. The introduction of Fe improved the acidity of SSZ-13 zeolite. The samples obtained by different preparation methods exhibit differences in strengths of weak and strong acids. Combined with findings for different acidity levels in Table 5, where Fe-SSZ-13-IM has the highest total acidity, especially in weak acidity exhibited, but Fe-SSZ-13-LIE has the advantage in terms of strong acidity enhancement. The significant acidic differences among all samples are also probably attributable to the presence and distribution of different Fe species. The role of specific acidic sites in catalysts should be further evaluated. 3.2.10 Py-FTIR Py-FTIR spectra was performed to elucidate on the acidity of the catalyst and to investigate the role of acidity in catalytic oxidation processes. Moreover, Py-FTIR was used to identify the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of the catalyst. In Fig. 12 , the three intense bands are respectively attributed to Lewis acid site (1445 cm−1), the Brønsted acid site (1549 cm−1), and the superimposed Brønsted and Lewis acid site (1490 cm−1) [46,47]. Quantification of Brønsted acid and Lewis acid sites was performed by Py-FTIR spectroscopy (Table 6 ). The ratios of Brønsted to Lewis acid sites for the catalysts decreased in the order: Fe-SSZ-13-LIE>Fe-SSZ-13-IM>Fe-SSZ-13-SSIE. These findings are in tandem with the experimental results of H2O2 oxidation of NO catalyzed by three iron-based catalysts, from which it can be concluded that the role of Brønsted acid is crucial in oxidative NO removal processes. 3.3 Relationship between active iron species with acidic sites and catalytic activities Catalytic activities of Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts obtained by different preparation methods in the NO oxidation process were investigated. Commercial SSZ-13 without iron loading and fly ash-based SSZ-13 zeolite were added for comparisons (Fig. 13 ). Although the catalytic performance of FA-SSZ-13 zeolite was not as good as that of commercial SSZ-13, it exhibited an NO removal efficiency of 55%, thereby achieving the purpose of “turning waste into treasure”. On the basis of iron loading of fly ash-based zeolite, the NO removal efficiency was significantly improved. In addition, although carrier structures in the three Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts were the same and Fe levels similar, the obtained NO removal efficiencies are not the same. Fe-SSZ-13-LIE showed the most satisfactory catalytic effect. Based on previous characterization analyses of catalysts, the activities of catalysts depend on type and dispersion of iron substances on the zeolite surface as well as acidity and concentration of the catalyst. The Fe-SSZ-13-LIE catalyst contains highly dispersed isolated Fe3+ ions and strong Brønsted acid properties on the SSZ-13 zeolite surface. These properties facilitate rapid decomposition of H2O2 with strong oxidizing abilities of hydroxyl radicals, which in turn enhances NO removal. To reveal the significance of Fe3+ species and Brønsted acid sites as active species and the role of hydroxyl radicals in oxidation processes. We used the Fe-SSZ-13-LIE catalyst as the study object, ·OH scavenging assays were performed to determine catalytic oxidation mechanisms in combination with removal efficiencies of NO. Findings from these assays are shown in supplementary data (Fig. S6). According to ·OH scavenging assays, addition of the ·OH scavenger (isopropanol) markedly suppressed the NO removal efficiency. The introduction of Fe led to different degrees of variations in pore properties, morphology, microstructural stability, acidity, Fe species and distribution, as well as in redox properties of zeolites. When Fe was introduced into zeolites, Fe species with different roles were formed both inside and outside the skeleton. These Fe species play different roles in catalytic reactions. H2-TPR, XPS and UV-vis analyses, showed that different Fe species coexist in Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts, with a slightly higher percentage of Fe2O3 particles in Fe-SSZ-13-IM, probably due to the presence of slight particle agglomeration with a fraction located outside the channels. All Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts with isolated Fe3+ and oligomeric FexOy are overwhelmingly represented, indicating that Fe species are well dispersed on the crystal surface, inside the channels and cages of SSZ-13 zeolites to enhance catalytic activities. The catalysts obtained by ion exchange had a relatively high proportion of Fe3+ ions, however, in Fe-SSZ-13-LIE obtained by liquid ion exchange, Fe mainly exists in form of isolated Fe3+ ions, while Fe-SSZ-13-LIE had the highest removal efficiency. According to a previous study [42] and ESR characterization analysis, it was found that the Fe-based catalysis of H2O2 generates hydroxyl radicals (·OH) with strong oxidizing abilities, and the ·OH can effectively oxidize NO. The NH3-TPD and Py-FTIR assays, combined with removal efficiency experiments, revealed that acidic sites, especially Brønsted acid sites, are of great importance in catalytic processes. In summary, catalytic oxidation mechanisms of NO removal can be described as: the redox cyclic process of Fe2+/Fe3+ occurs simultaneously on catalyst surfaces [48,49], that is, in the presence of H2O2, Fe3+ on the zeolite surface is reduced to Fe2+, which reacts with additional H2O2 to release ·OH, consistent with findings from other studies [25]. Besides, highly dispersed Fe species on the zeolite surface can provide sufficient active sites and large contact surfaces with H2O2 [39], which has a high loading capacity, while stabilizing the Fe species in catalysts. Strong interactions between this Fe species and the carrier has positive effects on catalytic performance. Incorporation of Fe into the zeolite framework enhances the concentration of Brønsted acid sites, which promotes catalytic oxidation reactions. Moreover, Brønsted acidity creates an acidic environment around the catalyst surface, significantly increasing the rate of ·OH generation as the presence of protons to balance the electronegativity of the framework. Therefore, the combination of having more isolated Fe3+ species and Brønsted acid sites endows Fe-SSZ-13-LIE with better catalytic performance. Catalytic oxidation mechanisms of NO removal with Fe-SSZ-13 combined with H2O2 are shown in by Fig. 14 . 4 Conclusions The FA-SSZ-13 zeolite was successfully synthesized from fly ash by alkali fusion combined with hydrothermal treatment. Optimal preparation parameters and the effects of preparation conditions on formation of the SSZ-13 zeolite were determined by XRD, FTIR and SEM characterization to enhance the physico-chemical properties. A series of fly ash-based Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts were obtained by three different methods: impregnation, liquid ion exchange and solid state ion exchange methods. Catalytic performances were assessed using various physicochemical techniques. Even though the distribution and states of Fe species in the Fe-based catalysts differed, as did the amounts of acidic sites, when combined with findings from NO removal experiments, it was established that Fe species and acidic sites affect the catalytic activities of Fe-SSZ-13 in NO oxidation by H2O2. Among them, Fe-SSZ-13-LIE had the best catalytic oxidation performance, which was attributed to abundance of isolated Fe3+ species and Brønsted acid density. Thus, Fe-based catalysts prepared by liquid ion exchange with fly ash-based SSZ-13 zeolite as the carrier are promising for applications, which not only expands the application pathway of high value-added products from fly ash, but also realizes the efficient removal of NO. coredata.dc:description: SSZ-13 zeolite was synthesized from fly ash using a combined alkali fusion hydrothermal method. The optimal synthesis parameters are as follows: NaOH/FA=1.4, SiO2/Al2O3=50, H2O/SiO2=1800, TMAda-OH/Al2O3=7, the amount of SSZ-13-seed=10%, and crystallization time and temperature were 160 °C and 40 h. Based on this, a series of fly ash-based Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts were prepared using three different methods and tested in catalytic oxidation with H2O2 for NO removal. The experiment results showed that the NO removal efficiency catalyzed by Fe-SSZ-13-SSIE, Fe-SSZ-13-LIE and Fe-SSZ-13-IM were 78%, 87% and 84%, respectively. ESR was used to detect hydroxyl radicals, UV-vis, XPS and H2-TPR were applied to test the composition, state and distribution of iron species, while NH3-TPD and Py-FTIR were performed to analyze the intensity and type of acidic sites, and finally to determine the relationship between catalyst structure, active species and catalytic performance in combination with NO removal experiments. The catalytic oxidation mechanism analysis revealed that the excellent catalytic performance can be attributed to the dual function of strong Brønsted acidity on the surface and isolated Fe3+ with high dispersion, which can rapidly decompose H2O2 into ·OH and efficiently achieve NO oxidation. In conclusion, the preparation of fly ash catalysts has great potential for achieving the dual function of waste utilization and pollutant removal.
coredata.dc:title: Studies on the preparation of fly ash-derived Fe-SSZ-13 catalysts and their performance in the catalytic oxidation of NO by H2O2
